posts.title: NYPL’s Mabel Williams: Giving Teens a Voice
posts.text: Mabel Williams's groundbreaking work of focusing library services on teens culminated with the creation of the Library's first “NYPL Books for Young People” list, which influenced school library collections across the nation.

posts.title: 30+ Bridgerton Readalikes to Steam Up All Your Nights
posts.text: Don't be discouraged if you're in a holds queue for one of the Bridgerton books—here are dozens of similar books to try while you wait.

posts.title: 22 Books for Fans of The Queen's Gambit
posts.text: As soon as I finished the series, I wanted non-fiction books about chess, chess history, obsession and young prodigies. I wanted fiction books that felt similar. Coming of age stories full of angst, psychological trauma and introspection. Stories with women and men dealing with past mistakes, family drama, the pitfalls of fame and discovering a found family. Stories with style. This is a selection of what I found.

posts.title: 125 ​Books We Love for Teens: A YA Librarian’s Tales of Censorship, Meeting Authors, Working with Teens and Falling in Love with Books
posts.text: One librarian's stories of the books, teens and authors who have impacted her life and career.

posts.title: New Orleans: A City Whose Truth is Stranger (and Better) than Fiction
posts.text: This year marks the 15th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina and its devastation of New Orleans. It’s a city that has clawed its way back from the brink. This booklist of memoirs and nonfiction paints a picture of the city it once was and the city it has now become.

posts.title: Women's Suffrage Reads for Fiction Lovers
posts.text: Adult, young adult and children's historical fiction, romances and mystery series set during the suffrage era and involving suffragists.

posts.title: Beach Read-palooza 2020!
posts.text: A beach read is in the eye of the beholder—it depends on what you want to read and what frame of mind you want to be in as you relax in the sun, shade or a/c.

posts.title: The Heir Affair and a Royal Romance Roundup
posts.text: A round-up of adult and young adult royal romances, old and new, to keep you busy all summer long.

posts.title: Dark Academia: Murder, Magic & Madness
posts.text: Dark magic, svengali professors, mentally disturbed students, psychotic cliques and vanishing friends...

posts.title: 30 Historical Mystery Series to Get You Through Any Crisis
posts.text: Foes are vanquished, crimes are solved and justice is almost always served—so much better than real life!

posts.title: A Daisy Jones & The Six Rock 'n' Roll Reading List
posts.text: If this novel about 1970s California rock 'n' roll has you listening to Fleetwood Mac, Crosby, Stills & Nash, and Joni Mitchell, this reading list—and Spotify playlist—is for you.

posts.title: 11 Ice Hot Hockey Romances
posts.text: You don't have to know the rules of everyone's favorite frozen sport to enjoy these steamy selections from a romance sub-genre you may not even know exists.

posts.title: 12 Cozy Reads for Christmas 2018
posts.text: In the midst of the holiday planning, take some time for yourself with one of our coziest recommendations for the season. Includes a Spotify playlist!

posts.title: 17 Readalikes for "To All The Boys I've Loved Before"
posts.text: You've finished Jenny Han's rom-com series (or are waiting to pick up the sequels). Now what? Check out these readalike recommendations!

posts.title: 15 Teen Romances to Steam Up Your Summer
posts.text: The following list of young-adult titles has it all: the sweet and the steamy, rated on a scale of 1 to 10. The higher the steam rating, the more likely the novel is to make you swoon.

posts.title: The Life and Work of Author Richard Peck, 1934 - 2018
posts.text: He left his career as a teacher in the 1970s, and went on to write more than 50 books for children, teens, and adults. We remember the wonderful bibliography of Richard Peck.

posts.title: A List Fit for a Royal Wedding
posts.text: HRH Prince Harry of Wales is marrying American actress and philanthropist Meghan Markle! Anyone else obsessed? Don't be embarrassed—check out our guide and booklist!

posts.title: Cozy Christmas Reads
posts.text: Here's a list of books filled with Christmas miracles, opposites attracting, lovers reuniting, families reconciling, happily ever afters, mysteries being solved and villains being vanquished—plus lots of snow and holiday merriment!

posts.title: Americans in World War One: History & Stories
posts.text: World War I is called "The Great War" but in America it could also be called "The Forgotten War." We started celebrating Veteran’s Day on November 11, 1919 as a way to commemorate the day that hostilities in World War I ended.

posts.title: Books with Autumnal Witchy Vibes
posts.text: Since we could all probably use a little hocus pocus in our lives, here is a list of books filled with witches, romance, magic, and autumn leaves.

posts.title: Very British (& Scottish) Romances
posts.text: Romance is the only genre where you essentially know the ending: two people will end up together. The who, what, where, and how of the story, however, are all up for grabs.

posts.title: Life, Liberty, & Romance
posts.text: The American Revolution was a turbulent time in American history, with great potential for romance as well as trauma. War, divided loyalties, danger around every corner, spies, intrigue, remote homes and forts, decadent Georgian society, men in uniform, women in corsets and dresses that leave little to the imagination, cozy fires to cuddle by... you get the picture. And we’ve found a handful of novels to make your July 4 that much more patriotic and passionate.

posts.title: Olivia's 8 Hot Books for a Cool Summer
posts.text: Olivia is an avid reader and patron of the Mulberry Street Library. As part of a school internship program she put together  this summer vacation book list and book display for the library.

posts.title: For the Love of Riverdale: Read-a-likes for Your Favorite TV Show
posts.text: An all-American teen is dead, a small town full of secrets and suspects. What could have happened to a teen with the seemingly perfect life? What secrets were they hiding?  Someone better find out the truth before another person turns up dead. If this sounds familiar, you may be a fan of Riverdale.

posts.title: 10 Reasons Teens Love the Mulberry Street Library
posts.text: In honor of Mulberry's 10th birthday, we asked the teens in our weekly teen lounge why they love the library.

posts.title: 13 Romance Novels Set in Cornwall
posts.text: Cornwall is a never-ending feast for the eyes: here are 13 romance novels guaranteed to transport you to those dream-laden shores.

posts.title: 10 More Best Books for Teens 2016
posts.text: The 2016 Best Books for Teens is a great list, but there are books I love that didn’t make the final cut. So to make sure these awesome books get their due, here are 10 fiction books I think should’ve made the list.

posts.title: Not-So Innocents Abroad: 10 YA Mysteries and Thrillers for the Dog Days of Summer
posts.text: Novels filled with thrills, action, suspense, murder, romance and all set in exotic and romantic locations around the world—perfect reads for the last days of summer.

posts.title: Boys of Summer: 15 YA Romances You'll Totally Fall For
posts.text: Every summer I put together a list of my favorite teen romance novels—new and old—to read during those lazy summer days. It always has a theme, but this year I’m keeping it simple.

posts.title: Remembering the Chills and Thrills of Lois Duncan, YA Lit Icon
posts.text: Pioneering Young Adult author, Lois Duncan passed away on June 6th at the age of 82. It's hard to believe that it's been almost 30 - 45 years since many of her teen novels were first published and they continue to have the power to spark the imagination and send shivers down the spine. If you haven't read one yet or read one lately, now's your chance.

posts.title: Feminist YA Fiction
posts.text: Novels that feature strong, female characters who either confront sexism, defy the patriarchal order, subvert gender expectations or celebrate female solidarity, or all of the above.

posts.title: Best Books for Teens 2015: Our Top 10 Favorites!
posts.text: It’s time for the second annual NYPL Best Books for Teens list! Get ready for the most memorable, the most gut-wrenching, the most exciting, the most fun, the most swoony, the most informative and the most engaging books of the year.

posts.title: Paranoia, the Devil, and Witchcraft: Books on the Salem Witch Trials
posts.text: Why did this happen and how could it have happened? You’ll have to read the accounts, the theories and stories and figure that part out for yourself. The following are recommended nonfiction and fiction books on the topic from children’s, YA and adult collections.

posts.title: 10 New YA Romances That Will Give You Feels
posts.text: I've rated the following books by the amount of swooning involved and the magnitude of life lessons.

posts.title: So You've Read "Paper Towns," Now What?
posts.text: Here are other books filled with friends, road trips, elusive and mysterious dream girls (and dream boys) who force us out of our comfort zones and universal truths about life, love and living in the moment.

posts.title: Books About Trans and Non-bianary Teens
posts.text: Teen literature spends a good proportion of its existence taking on tough topics, shedding light on what it means to be different and how we strive to become our most authentic selves. So it should come as a surprise to no one that teen lit has been showcasing the courageous, true and fictional, stories of transgender teens, teens struggling with gender identity and teens dealing with transgender friends and family members for years.

posts.title: A Summer of "Rogues" and Romance
posts.text: If you’re Regency romance fan and have yet to read a Company of Rogues novel by Jo Beverley, then boy do I have a summer challenge/project for you!

posts.title: Fantasy of Power and Betrayal: "Game of Thrones" Readalikes for Teens
posts.text: A recent trend in YA Lit is the fantasy sub-genre: court and political intrigue fantasy. It’s full of all the stuff that makes for great high stakes drama:  power, family, politics, love, betrayal, swords, treachery, corruption, duplicity, vengeance, manipulation, secrets, nefarious plots, fighting, revenge, occasionally some dragons and usually, a good healthy dose of flirtation and swoon.

posts.title: How did YA Become YA?
posts.text: “Why is it called YA anyway? And who decided what was YA and what wasn’t?” The short answer: librarians.

posts.title: Waiting for "Downton Abbey" 2015!
posts.text: It’s going to be rough wait, but we will do it together and somehow find other books and films to fill the Downton-sized hole in our hearts.

posts.title: Waiting for "Outlander"
posts.text: Way way back, in 1990, I wandered into a Portland, Oregon bookstore and found a romance novel, set in Scotland, involving time travel and I was hooked! Since then, it’s been a 25 year odyssey of reading and waiting. Outlander finally returns to TV on April 4.

posts.title: The Legacy of Kurt Cobain and Nirvana in YA Fiction
posts.text: In the rain soaked Seattle of the early '90s, grunge rock was the soundtrack to our lives and Kurt and Nirvana were at its center. Twenty one years on, his legacy continues in two recent YA books Carnival at Bray and Love Letters to the Dead. Both books examine the power of music and words to bring people together, inspire us and give us hope.

posts.title: Thrills, Chills and Romance: The New Gothic Genre
posts.text: Do you shiver at the thought of winds whistling down the Yorkshire moors and waves crashing against the Cornish coast? Wrap yourself up in one of these cozy gothic romance titles.

posts.title: The Legacy of Walter Dean Myers
posts.text: What made Walter Dean Myers stand out was his tireless belief that the telling and reading of all kinds of stories mattered, that teens mattered, communities and families mattered, and that libraries and librarians mattered.

posts.title: A Sucker for Romance: 2014 YA Books Guaranteed to Make You Swoon!
posts.text: Romance titles that didn't make our Top 25, but that will still make your heart go pitter-pat.

posts.title: Best Books for Teens 2014!
posts.text: The list includes a selection of 25 novels, non-fiction books, and graphic novels chosen by a committee of Young Adult librarians who work with teens in NYPL’s neighborhood branches.

posts.text: A track by track review of their new album, by a “1D AF.”

posts.title: What to Read Next: Spies & Assassins and John Green/TFIOS Read-a-Likes
posts.text: Summertime and the living is easy or so they say. All that free time but what to do? More importantly what to read? There’s way too many choices these days and what happens when you go into a library and they don’t have what you’re looking for? Ugh, so frustrating! You do have a few choices: you can browse the shelves, you can ask a friend or a trusted librarian for recommendations, check the Summer Reading book lists or... you can read this post. I’ve researched some of the most ask for genres at branches and compiled some great read-alikes. Surely there’s something here that’ll

posts.title: Guitars, Gigs, Girls (& Guys): Four Lists of Teen Books that Rock!
posts.text: Books and plots involving music, musicians, fans and bands go together like peanut butter and jelly. In other words, perfectly! They’re pretty much a top 10 sub-genre of YA fiction for me and here’s why.

posts.title: New York Punk Rock: A Basic History
posts.text: The theme for Anti-Prom 2014 is New York Punk Rock. The golden age of punk rock in NYC was from 1974 to 1981. When clubs like CBGBs and Max's Kansas City ruled the scene and bands like Television, The Ramones, Blondie, Suicide and Patti Smith were its kings and queens.

posts.title: Bewitched, Bothered and Betrothed: An Intro to Gaslamp Fantasy
posts.text: "Gaslamp Fantasy" is essentially a sub-genre of Steampunk Fantasy. But, whereas Steampunk often involves gadgets and mad scientists in an alternate Victorian universe, Gaslamp stories are set in a magical version of the 19th century, think Jane Austen or Charles Dickens meets Harry Potter. The stories can take place at any time between the Regency Era (early 1800s) all the way up to the beginning of WWI (1914). You'll find historical settings, gothic ambience, ballrooms, wit and romance, witches, dark magic, fairies and all manner of supernatural creatures but very little science.

Hot Historical Fiction Part Two: The Tudors, Fairies, Ladies, and Fools
posts.text: Okay, I confess, I am a history geek and an Anglophile, meaning I am sucker for anything with a bit of British history and culture. However, that doesn’t mean dry, boring or high brow. I still insist that the historical novels I read be interesting, fun to read, and perhaps romantic, and if they have magical elements, even better! The fairies, witty dialogue, and romance may pull you in, but you finish the book with a better understanding of history and society without even realizing it.
